title: Prudent
definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
phrase: Auditors have praised Greenwich Council for its prudent management of public money.
swords: separately, individually, singly, discretely
examples: 'The two new products will be linked to endowment and pension plans respectively.'

title: Respectively
definition: Separately or individually and in the order already mentioned.
phrase: These score eight and seven out of 10 respectively in terms of adding value to an existing home.
swords: forestall, prevent
examples: 'Often the coup is undertaken to pre-empt revolutionary change from below and impose a measure of reform from above.'

title: Pre-empt
definition: Take action in order to prevent (an anticipated event) happening; Prevent.
phrase: First, it is clear the authorities did little or nothing to pre-empt the events of last year.
swords: forestall, prevent
examples: 'Often the coup is undertaken to pre-empt revolutionary change from below and impose a measure of reform from above.'

title: Permeate
definition: Spread throughout (something); pervade.
phrase: The idea that education permeates every aspect of life seems to have fallen by the wayside.
swords: pervade, spread through, fill, filter through, diffuse through, imbue, penetrate, pass through
examples: 'He is emblematic of the good fun and sense of community that permeates this weekly event.'

title: Partisan
definition: A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
phrase: The numerous controversies between State advocates and partisans of private initiative explain this lag.
swords: supporter, follower, adherent, devotee, champion, backer, upholder, promoter
examples: 'True democracy is dreaded by partisans of the old left and right alike.'

title: Objective
definition: not influenced by personal feelings or opinions in considering and representing facts.
phrase: historians try to be objective and impartial
swords: impartial, unbiased, neutral, uninvolved, even-handed, equitable, fair
examples: 'Any objective person would have to say that over the last four years we have invested more particularly in cancer services than we did in the past twenty years.'

title: Maverick
definition: An unorthodox or independent-minded person.
phrase: They want independent minds, mavericks and free thinkers.
swords: individualist, free spirit, original, trendsetter, bohemian, eccentric
examples: 'A maverick, and an individual, he's running on instinct, fuelled by experience and making the right decisions.'

title: Bygone
definition: Belonging to an earlier time.
phrase: relics of a bygone age
swords: past, former, earlier, one-time, long-ago, gone by, previous, forgotten
examples: 'The Street administration portrays the mounted unit as a relic of a bygone era.'

title: Artless
definition: Without effort or pretentiousness; natural and simple.
phrase: an artless literary masterpiece
swords: natural, naive, simple, innocent, childlike, pure, ingenuous, guileless, candid
examples: 'His prose is artless and nowhere near as polished as Osborne's, but his book still tells a fascinating story.'

title: Apathy
definition: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
phrase: We may not be able to institute change, but apathy is the death of all dialogue and debate.
swords: indifference, lack of interest, lack of enthusiasm, lack of concern, unconcern
examples: 'This shows apathy on the part of the Government to the problems of the common man.'

title: Levy
definition: Impose a tax, fee, or fine on; Collect tax from.
phrase: a tax of two per cent was levied on all cargoes
swords: impose, charge, exact, demand, raise, collect, gather
examples: 'Taxes are levied on the basis of income and property.'

title: Germane
definition: Relevant to a subject under consideration.
phrase: That is not germane to our theme.
swords: relevant, pertinent, applicable, apposite, material
examples: 'It is therefore necessary that certain points germane to the subject be discussed in detail.'

title: Foreshadow
definition: Be a warning or indication of (a future event).
phrase: These dreams are invariably important, and often foreshadow events in the near future.
swords: augur, presage, portend, prognosticate, foreshow, foretell, indicate, suggest, signal
examples: 'This impression is not quite accurate but does foreshadow events to come.'

title: Ephemeral
definition: Lasting for a very short time.
phrase: fashions are ephemeral: new ones regularly drive out the old
swords: transitory, transient, fleeting, passing, short-lived, momentary, brief, short
examples: 'The pictures reflect an interest in the ephemeral, impermanent, transient nature of the world.'

title: Deterrent
definition: Something that restrains or discourages.
phrase: The concentration of wealth and power is a great deterrent to democracy.
swords: disincentive, discouragement, dissuasion, damper, brake, curb, check, restraint
examples: 'These penalties will hopefully act as a deterrent to anybody else thinking of abusing or assaulting a referee.'

title: Concede
definition: Admit or agree that something is true after first denying or resisting it.
phrase: I had to concede that I'd overreacted.
swords: normal, standard, usual, typical, stock, ordinary, customary, conventional
examples: 'All parties, including the government and the suppliers conceded the evidence as true.'

title: Chauvinism
definition: Exaggerated or aggressive patriotism.
phrase: public opinion was easily moved to chauvinism and nationalism.
swords: jingoism, excessive patriotism, blind patriotism, excessive nationalism, sectarianism, isolationism
examples: 'A definite environment has been created of blind patriotism and chauvinism.'

title: Balk
definition: Hesitate or refuse to do something.
phrase: he balked at such a drastic solution.
swords: eschew, resist, refuse to, be unwilling to, draw the line at, be reluctant to, draw back from
examples: 'At first she balked at the idea, saying she no longer performed those pieces.'

title: Facade
definition: A deceptive outward appearance.
phrase: She was behind a mask of facades, and at the moment, so was I.
swords: front, appearance, false display, pretence, illusion, posture, pose, sham, fake, ac, guise, mask, cloak
examples: 'But behind his flawless English facade is a Celtic streak which has fuelled his career.'

title: Default
definition: An option that is selected automatically unless an alternative is specified
phrase: The program will choose a default filename for you.
swords: normal, standard, usual, typical, stock, ordinary, customary, conventional
examples: 'Stephen informed us that there is such an option in the software but that the default setting is off.'

title: Diffidence
definition: Modesty or shyness resulting from a lack of self-confidence.
phrase: I say this with some diffidence
swords: shyness, modesty, modestness, humility, humbleness, timidness, timorousness, reserve
examples: 'It is with diffidence and humility that I greet the ultimate constitutional power in the Republic, the Presidential electors.'

title: Dichotomy
definition: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
phrase: a rigid dichotomy between science and mysticism.
swords: division, separation, divorce, split, gulf, chasm
examples: 'The old dichotomies begin to collapse as artists emphasize their sense of symbiosis with, rather than detachment from, Nature.'

title: Confound
definition: Cause surprise or confusion in (someone).
phrase: I was confounded by this unexpected rationality.
swords: amaze, astonish, stagger, surprise, startle, stun, stupefy, daze
examples: 'In only a few years, it won't just be the Web that confounds you, it will be your personal computer.'

title: Decorum
definition: Behaviour in keeping with good taste and propriety.
phrase: he had acted with the utmost decorum.
swords: propriety, properness, seemliness, decency, decorousness, appropriacy
examples: 'They are patterns of behaviour or patterns of decorum that we all have,’ says MacArthur.'

title: Castigate
definition: Reprimand (someone) severely.
phrase: A friend used to castigate me for not wearing a belt.
swords: reprimand, rebuke, admonish, upbraid, reprove, reproach, scold,
examples: 'He had castigated the team for, among other things, unprofessionalism and indiscipline.'

title: Belie
definition: fail to give a true impression of (something).
phrase: His tone of voice and the look in his eyes completely belied his words.
swords: contradict, disprove, debunk, discredit, explode
examples: 'Its exotic appearance belies the toughness and reliability of its nature.'

title: Banal
definition: so lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
phrase: songs with banal, repeated words
swords: clichéd, commonplace, ordinary, common, conventional, stereotyped, predictable
examples: 'I find most New Age spiritual music to be boring and banal but I've met a lot of people that find great use for it.'

title: Aesthetic
definition: concerning or characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste.
phrase: the pictures give great aesthetic pleasure
swords: decorative, graceful, elegant, exquisite, beautiful, attractive, pleasing, lovely, stylish
examples: 'The art on the walls was contemporary and unusual, creating an ambience of aesthetic appreciation.'

title: Caustic
definition: Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
phrase: the players were making caustic comments about the refereeing.
swords: sarcastic, sharp, bitter, scathing, derisive, sardonic, ironic, scornful
examples: 'I am continually surprised by Sharon's creativity even if it is currently directed towards caustic but witty sarcasm.'

title: Adulterate
definition: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance.
phrase: the brewer is said to adulterate his beer
swords: degrade, debase, spoil, taint, defile, contaminate, pollute, foul, sully
examples: 'The authorities, especially, the health department, should take stringent action against those who are adulterating food.'

title: Anecdotal
definition: not necessarily true or reliable.
phrase: I have my own theories on this, but they are based purely on anecdotal evidence.
swords: informal, unreliable, based on hearsay; unscientific
examples:
'Theory is paraded as fact, anecdotal accounts as hard data.'
'Some effect measurements are based on anecdotal evidence.'

title: Admonish
definition: scold, reprimand firmly.
phrase: she admonished me for appearing at breakfast unshaven
swords: lecture, criticize,reprove, upbraid, chastise, chide, censure, castigate, lambaste, berate, reproach
examples: 'It is important that you don't chastise or admonish yourself for your feelings.'

title: Imminent
definition: About to happen.
phrase: they were in imminent danger of being swept away
swords: impending, at hand, close, near, approaching, fast approaching, coming, forthcoming, on the way
examples: 'In the new era which Mark believes is dawning, the temple is rejected and its imminent destruction is expected.'

title: Providential
definition: Occurring at a favourable time; opportune.
phrase: his appearance had seemed more than just providential
swords: opportune, advantageous, favourable, auspicious, propitious, heaven-sent, lucky
examples: 'It was providential that he purchased this exceptional pen and he took the trouble to research its history.'

title: Disparate
definition: Essentially different in kind; not able to be compared.
phrase: they inhabit disparate worlds of thought
swords: contrasting, different, differing, dissimilar, unlike, unalike, poles apart
examples: 'The difference between those and these findings may be due the disparate methodologies used.'

title: Plausible
definition: seeming reasonable or probable.
phrase: it seems plausible that one of two things may happen
swords: credible, reasonable, believable, feasible, possible, conceivable, imaginable
examples: 'A reasoning becomes plausible if it is logical and if there is empirical support.'

title: Sanguine
definition: Optimistic or positive.
phrase: he is sanguine about prospects for the global economy
swords: optimistic, bullish, hopeful, buoyant, positive, confident
examples: 'the committee takes a more sanguine view'

title: Abscond
definition: Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
phrase: the barman absconded with a week's takings.
swords: run away, escape, bolt, clear out, flee, make off, take flight, take off, fly, decamp
examples: 'She is enjoying significant unescorted ground leave and has not endeavoured to abscond.'

title: Revere
definition: Feel deep respect or admiration for (something).
phrase: We will always love you, and revere your amazing grace in that wonderful season.
swords: respect, admire, esteem, hold in (high) esteem
examples: 'Survivals from the earliest centuries of Christianity were also revered among their treasures'

title: Venerate
definition: Regard with great respect; revere.
phrase: Philip of Beverley was venerated as a saint
swords: revere, reverence, respect, worship, adulate, idolize, exalt, honour, esteem
examples: 'Big corporations tend to treat venerated logos with deep respect.'

title: Succinct
definition: briefly and clearly expressed.
phrase: use short, succinct sentences
swords: concise, short, brief, compact, crisp, laconic, to the point, economic, thumbnail, summary
examples: 'Her crisp and succinct discussion of dowry is sure to remain the classic analysis of this subject.'

title: Ingenious
definition: clever, original, and inventive.
phrase: he was ingenious enough to overcome the limited budget
swords: inventive, creative, insightful, inspired, perceptive, intuitive
examples: 'The filmmakers were quite ingenious in imposing the needs of the medium on their depiction of Nash.'

title: Meticulous
definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
phrase: the designs are hand-glazed with meticulous care
swords: careful, painstaking, demanding, exacting, accurate, correct
examples: 'he had always been so meticulous about his appearance'

title: Erudite
definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
phrase: Ken could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion
swords: learned, scholarly, knowledgeable, lettered, cultured, cultivated, civilized, intellectual
examples:
'she was very erudite'
'The Clinton debate was, it turned out, an unusually erudite discussion.'

title: Fastidious
definition: very careful and attentive.
phrase: she dressed with fastidious care
swords: scrupulous, punctilious, perfectionist, fussy, finicky, dainty
examples:
'The central characters are fastidious, scrupulous and articulate.'
'Aside from this fastidious attention to detail, the designer's work has few distinguishing features.'

title: Euphoric
definition: Characterized by or feeling intense excitement and happiness.
phrase: The atmosphere was euphoric even before we took the lead.
swords: elated, happy, joyful, joyous, delighted, animated, jubilant, exultant, ecstatic, blissful
examples: 'You want to know when I'm happy or sad, tired, glad, euphoric, if I just got piece, whatever.'

title: Enigma
definition: A person or thing that is mysterious or difficult to understand.
phrase: What is left is the puzzle and the enigma that we need to figure out.
swords: mystery, puzzle, riddle, conundrum, paradox, problem, question mark, quandary
examples: 'It is often felt that death is an enigma, perhaps the ultimate mystery.'

title: Pedant
definition: a person who is excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning.
phrase: The questioner is shouted down, accused of being a grammatical pedant.
swords: dogmatist, purist, literalist, formalist, doctrinaire; precisionist, perfectionist
examples: 'I like that sentence and I don't care what grammatical pedants think.'

title: Abeyance
definition: A state of temporary disuse or suspension.
phrase: matters were held in abeyance pending further enquiries
swords: suspension, a state of suspension, a state of dormancy, a state of latency, a state of uncertainty, suspense, remission, reserve
examples: 'This meant escalation of the pain that had been held in abeyance.'

title: Pragmatic
definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
phrase: a pragmatic approach to politics.
swords: down-to-earth, earthy, hardheaded, matter-of-fact, practical, realistic.
examples: 'All three authors point out that as a composer Stravinsky was very pragmatic.'

title: Bolster
definition: support or strengthen.
phrase: Place a firm bolster against the wall.
swords: strengthen, support, reinforce, make stronger, boost, fortify, give a boost to
examples:
'They took high premiums to bolster up the funds.'
'the fall in interest rates is starting to bolster confidence'

title: Soporific
definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
phrase: the motion of the train had a somewhat soporific effect.
swords: sleep-inducing, somnolent, sedative, calmative, tranquillizing, narcotic, opiate, drowsy, sleepy, somniferous
examples:
'some medicine made her soporific'
'Instead, I stood mesmerised by his soporific chanting.'

title: Fervid
definition: intensely enthusiastic or passionate, especially to an excessive degree.
phrase: his fervid protestations of love
swords: ardent, blazing, burning, charged, emotional, hot-blooded, incandescent, intense, passional, passionate
examples: 'I don't have the feeling that he is a fervid prosecutor in the sense that he thinks that anyone accused of something must be guilty.'

title: Auspicious
definition: Conducive to success; favourable.
phrase: it was not the most auspicious moment to hold an election.
swords: favourable, propitious, promising, full of promise, bright, rosy, good, optimistic, hopeful, encouraging
examples:
'This is an auspicious moment for our company,’ says its co-founder.'
'It was not an auspicious moment to make their dream a reality.'

title: Engender
definition: cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition).
phrase: the issue engendered continuing controversy.
swords: produce, create, generate, arouse, rouse, provoke, incite, kindle, trigger
examples:
'It engenders feelings of belief in what can be achieved.'
'Many of these changes engender anxiety and fear.'

title: Aberrant
definition: Departing from an accepted standard.
phrase: this somewhat aberrant behaviour requires an explanation.
swords: abnormal, anomalous, atypical, especial, exceeding, exceptional, extraordinary, freak, odd, peculiar, phenomenal, rare, singular, uncommon, unique, unusual
examples:
'This year for some aberrant reason, I feel like watching, so let's all watch together.'
'In fact, it covers two of my many aberrant fields of interest.'

title: Ameliorate
definition: make something better, become better.
phrase: The reform did much to ameliorate living standards.
swords: alleviate, lighten, mitigate, amend, help, improve, meliorate, relieve, upgrade, step up
examples:
'the reform did much to ameliorate living standards'
'The humour ameliorates the violence in the statement.'

title: Laconic
definition: brief and to the point; effectively cut short.
phrase: Jessica is so talkative that her sister thought the situation warranted conciseness, and her being laconic.
swords: brief, concise, terse, succinct, short, economical, elliptical, crisp, pithy, to the point, incisive, short and sweet, compendious
examples:
'The problem is likely to be, at least in part, Hilberg's laconic style.'
'his laconic reply suggested a lack of interest in the topic.'

title: Profound
definition: very great or intense; thoughtful.
phrase: The experience had a very profound effect on me, both emotionally and spiritually.
swords: heartfelt, intense, keen, great, very great, extreme
examples:
'Such films can never have a profound influence on the viewers, he says'.
'I think it has quite profound implications for us as human beings.'

title: Abate
definition: become less intense or widespread; to reduce; lessen; diminish.
phrase: The storm suddenly abated.
swords: decrease, lessen, diminish, reduce, lower, dampen
examples:
'nothing abated his crusading zeal.'
'energy efficiency may be the quickest way to abate emissions of carbon dioxide.'
